I disagree - the core problem is "local control" of education (a myth in practice - and a farce otherwise), relying primarily on property taxes, which give wealthier communities an unfair advantage to begin with.
And the fix isn't simply changing the tax-deductability of these supplements (property taxes are already deductible - if you're wealthy enough to file a Schedule A).
The fix is collecting more taxes from wealthier districts and providing more funding to poorer ones, across the entire country, not just within a town's boundaries.
An astute analysis of one way we perpetuate our class system, and what might be done to improve matters.

Imagine reaching into a volcano, using a metal grappling device suspended from a crane. Extract as much molten magma, or in this case a molten fissile core of red-hot uranium fuel. No success? Try again, and again for a few thousand years as the molten core, spews dozens of different and deadly isotopes into the atmosphere. Continue, for years, as your work area becomes unlivable due to the unavailability of breathable air, food or drinking water or even a safe place to lay your head in the evening. Add death by rad-poisoning and rad-induced cancers in the ever decreasing work force. These are the plain, simple and practical reasons why no scenario for remediation has been developed for this or any other melt-down of a reactor core. The slow, irreversible drift downward of this Dantesque nightmare is the plan. It will burrow deep enough to cover itself, until, unreachable by any engineering methods currently available to our misguided and impotent race, we will place a marble stone over it as a warning to future explorers who wish to inhabit the then dead islands of the western Pacific rim.

I just checked out Raphael's 'School of Athens'. There are 40+ men. No women. That's not a group of 'people'. It is simply a group of 'men'. Given the subject of this article, I'm puzzled at your pleasure of the painting.

I always hated the first class in any subject.
Less defining the subject matter and more talking about the subject matter is my preference.

Rosa, it's a painting made in the Renaissance, depicting philosphers who lived thousands of years ago. What would you have had Rafael do, depict female philosophers when in fact Greek society of the time treated women as distinctly second-class citizens? Or do you think that we should ignore the remarkable contributions of these men because women were not allowed to join the club?

Those ancient Athenians had slaves, too, and did many other things that we find unacceptable. And yet we owe them an immeasurable debt.

A fabulous piece! It is an interesting question how the caricatures get a grip. I started my intro philosophy lecture today (prior to the publication of this piece) with three paintings depicting philosophers -- a Rembrandt, with the lone philosopher sitting under the stairs, contemplating with no trace of the outside world, a Fragonard, with a deranged looking man, hair flying every which way, buried in a book, and Raphael's School of Athens, with a group of people in a public space, talking with one another in the thick of things. As I said to the students, I prefer to think of philosophy as more like what is depicted in the Raphael than in the other two, and that is the kind of model for the class to be working with. Philosophers need more group photos!

Nicholas, I have such contempt right now!

The Syrian war did not begin a couple of years ago and the US involvement will not have begun when the first US bombs are dropped. Wars are decades in the making and then events bring us to the point, as they have now, where we wring our hands and say a military response is the only choice. Well, it is the only choice because we failed to prevent it from becoming the only choice.

The United Nations, or a new organization if this one is beyond redemption, must be restructured so that it can affect its mission of settling disputes peacefully. It must have the power to destroy chemical and atomic weapons and prevent new ones from being created. It must have frequent meetings that bring the world leaders together to discuss meaningful policies to prevent conflicts. And we need an effective international court that can apprehend, try and convict persons who commit such massive crimes against humanity as have individuals in the Syrian government and in some of the Syrian opposition groups.

I went high school in Oakland California (49-52) and of course the cooking classes were all girls. Then one of the guys took one of the classes, there were no restrictions, we just did not take "girls"classes.

It also turned out that the girls liked guys who cooked. There was a group of us that would meet after school in a coffee shop across the street from the school. Some of us have kept our contacts all these years.

I learned to cook from my grandmother who was a country girl, she was the one that cut the heads off the chickens, so could could cook decent, but no fancy gourmet stuff.

But after a divorce finding myself in a small condo, I had to resort to cooking all my own meals, and then discovered that inviting some lady over for dinner, and cooking nice meal was a good way to begin a relationship.

"Timely" column Nick. And, your wrist-pointing experiment is insightful. I'm a boomer, but like many younger people, we have mostly given up wearing watches -- as timepieces. Expensive watches only add "complications". Most watches are devolving -- into vestigial pieces of decorative jewelry. Perhaps only worn with a business suit, as an traditional accessory or personal statement, like a tie, pocket square, or cufflinks.

Most of the day, my internal sense of time is sufficiently accurate to guess at the time +/- five minutes. For more precise times (priority alarms, parking meters, billable time, etc.) I just reach for my iPhone. Or perhaps, dig deeper into your experiment, with that wonderful conversation-opening line: "Pardon me, do you have the time?"

Re Casio, Samsung, et al "smart" watches: They may be too much smart, and not enough wise. (IMHO) Apple's management is experienced enough to know when first-to-market innovation is a real competitive advantage (e.g. Macintosh, iPhone, iPad), and when to hold back a bit and avoid the first innovator's risks (e.g. Newton).

In addition, Apple is genetically encoded to "Simplify!". Apple's most astute designers have already discovered that any wrist-worn object-of-desire is best conceived as a not-too-big not-too-smart minimalist device. A nimble satellite -- in digital thrall to the global power of the iPhone (in my pocket, still evolving).

In the middle ages (1963) when I went to college, I don't remember anyone buying that much stuff. In the first place the women's college I attended was run on the lines of a convent/prison
and the many rules prohibited any applicances in dorm rooms which were very small. We all had to share a common living area where there were some rudimentary appliances to heat soup, etc. There just was no place to put a lot of stuff in the room and the main purchase was usually buying a coordinating bedspread with your roomate. I think the idea of the college was not to cocoon in your room by reproducing home comforts, but getting out and doing new things and meeting new people. In our everyday life we all basically lived on the same level and this was a great help to the not so affluent students of which I was one. I think I would have felt intimidated and just plain poor if I had been faced with lavishly appointed dorm rooms while mine was just very basic. I don't mean to imply there was universal equality, but the rules mandating certain living conditions helped level the playing field.
I didn't buy my daughter much beyond some bedding when she went to college because we had to travel 3,000 miles from home and because I come from a different tradition. A lot of the buying is due to parents & students falling for successful marketing. The goal is not to reproduce home at school, but to learn and live differently.

Toast and tomato is manna from heaven (particularly with a grind of black pepper and some basil).
BUT, so is toast and sliced strawberries or peaches, cherries, plums, you name it. Concerned about them falling off? Squish them a little onto the toast. Works just as well with bread, crackers etc.
We're used to jam because preserving was necessary for year-round food supply. With fruit readily available this is no longer the case.
Make your own sugar-free raw jam by blitzing small quantities of raw fruit, eg. berries, stone fruits in a small food processor or with a stick blender. Keep in the fridge and use within a few days.
You've seen the sugar-contents in above comments; ripe fruit doesn't need more.
If your taste buds aren't trained to live without sugar, add a little orange juice (freshly-squeezed) or stevia if you must. Or just add a weeny bit of real unprocessed (raw) sugar.
Bought jam is easy but usually made with over 50% total weight in sugar - to give it long shelf-life.
That morning bagel sounds wonderful but its waiting for some sliced strawberries...!

Make your own jam. Don't add sugar to sweet fruit. Just boil the fruit with a bit of fresh orange juice/zest and vanilla extract until you like the consistency. It keeps unfrozen in fridge for about 2-3 weeks, frozen indefinitely: I have have 2 containers of plum jam that are a year old, good because they were frozen free of all air.
We had something like 500 apples on our tree this year, referred to by a friend as a "blizzard". The fallen ones were made into applesauce with cinnamon, allspice, orange juice, vanilla. It beats anything one can buy.
We are so conditioned to think we have to buy things. We can make them, and will eat better because of it. The homemade jam is the fruit, only cooked and spiced, not like the concoction of whatever corporate food is.

Make your own!  I made peach/rosemary/ginger jam this year with the bounty from my trees -- no sugar needed, whole fruit, with grated ginger (more fiber) lemon juice and zest, and rosemary.  With the water bath canning, took an afternoon of work to peel, chop, reduce and can the fruit.  Oh and it tastes better than anything you could buy!

Can fruits be eaten with equal benefit in jam/jelly form?

Not sure if we are allowed to mention brand names but try Welch's reduced sugar grape jelly with 1/2 the sugar of regular and see if you dont like it twice as much. Taking the stimulus of sugar out really brings out the mellow berry flavor. Wish the same were done for, say, blueberries.

I do badly on fats, much better on carbs, meatless diet. I thrive on a breakfast of toasted multi grain bagel with low fat cream cheese and reduced sugar grape jelly, with coffee of course. It has been an improvement over my previous staple of oatmeal, banana and low sugar organic soy which sounds so healthy. Not sure why.

Here's a suggestion I have not heard from any politician, though I hope it’s being pursued behind the scenes. Syria’s ally Iran recently elected a relatively moderate President whose statements have been remarkably free of hostility to the US. His country has expressed some embarrassment at the use of chemical weapon in Syria. The US should test his conciliatory tone, and aim to engage Iran to help broker some kind of settlement. Like a “limited military strike”, this may not work, though its odds are much better; but, unlike military action, it cannot make things worse and could make them better.

President Obama, here's your chance to earn your Nobel Peace Prize. Pull back the dogs of war, pick up the phone and call Tehran.
